title: [css][html] SVG language support

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
Currently, we have no SVG support:

- In HTML, SVG tags don't receive auto completion
- In CSS, SVG attributes don't receive auto completion
- Syntax highlighting are problematic for both SVG tags/attributes in HTML/CSS
- Emmet do not get SVG completions

However, with custom tag/property support in HTML/CSS, we should be able to trivially write a SVG package that describes the set of tags/attributes for SVG, and let HTML/CSS language services do the support work.

- https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/62976
- https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/64164

title: Option to disable "Failed to save '...': The content on disk is newer." check
body:
I would like an option to disable dirty write checking:

> Failed to save 'xyz': The content on disk is newer. Please compare your version with the one on disk.

My workflow does include dirty writes and having to go through the merging is annoying.

Example: keeping dirty state in an open file then switching git branch to save and commit (that file only), then switching back to the previous branch.

title: Intellisense's 'Suggest selection' should keep working when you have typed something
body:
VSCode has a feature that remembers recent completions the user has selected and then automatically choosen those completions for them the next time. 
The problem is that it behaves quite oddly, and here is an example that illustrates why:

- Create a new Typescript file.
- Type `console.` vscode will suggest all of the available methods of `console`.
 - Choose `exception`.
- Type `console.` again. Vscode will immediately suggest `exception`, as expected.
And now here is the weird part: Type `e`, and instead of still suggesting `exception`, it will suggest `error`!

The problem here is that once you type anything after the suggestion came, vscode will completely disregard your completion history and will just give you the best match lexicographically. Even if in the example you have completed `exception` by typing an `e` and then having it complete it, the same thing will occur.
My suggestion is that when you have already typed something, the 'suggest selection' will just be filtered by what you have typed, instead of stop working. So in the example, after you have typed `e`, it will still suggest `exception`.

_"Switch the Suggest Selection settings to "recentlyUsedByPrefix" and it will work!"_
Yes it does make it sometimes work but overall it makes the situation much worse. For example if you type just `console.` it won't suggest exception no matter what you have done before.

title: Unexpected intellisense order with underscore prefix
body:
Maybe it's always done this and I'm only just hitting this, I think _addons should score best here:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2193314/50672376-91f37380-0f8c-11e9-95b2-36b6f8bcfacc.png)

Also the fact that the s and n are out of order in the best match is weird.

Not sure if this is TS or our algorithm?

title: Scroll bar visibility should be configurable
body:
### VSCode Version

![vs code version](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9283914/50669766-7194da80-0fc7-11e9-929a-6181fcc45f62.png)

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open Visual Studio code and open a large text file

### Current Behaviour

In Visual Studio Code, editors' scroll bars auto hide, thereby thwarting targeting the scroll bar handle when moving the mouse.

### Expected Behaviour

Visual Studio Code should follow the Windows system setting `Settings > Ease of Access > Display > Automatically hide scrollbar in Windows`

![scrollbar-always-visible-windows10](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9283914/50670087-6b9ff900-0fc9-11e9-91ac-b2d1e032ddfe.jpg)

### Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?
- [x] Yes
- [ ] No

title: Cannot resize Keyboard Shortcuts column sizes -> Add column resize handle bars and horizontal scroll bar

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
### Visual Studio Code Version
![vs code version](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9283914/50669483-be77b180-0fc5-11e9-983a-d59cdde245c6.png)

### Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open Visual Studio Code with default window size.
2. Create two editor groups horizontally.
3. Open Keyboards Shortcuts editor and resize editor group so the editor's content won't fit.

Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?
- [x] Yes
- [ ] No

### Screenshot

![vs code key bindings](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9283914/50669579-41990780-0fc6-11e9-9da7-1f520c685454.png)

### Current Result

You are not able to read the columns' contents or get to read the currently selected keyboard shortcut.

### Expected Result

1. Column handle bars should provide for resizing each of the columns. Double-clicking a column's right border should resize the column to optimum width.
2. A horizontal scrollbar should provide for scrolling through the Keyboards Shortcuts table horizontally if the horizontal size of the table exceeds the editor panel's width.

title: Auto-run task on folder close in addition to open

milestone.title: On Deck
milestone.description:
The Issues assigned to the **On Deck** milestone under consideration for the upcoming milestones.
Our goal is to always have less than 100 Issues on deck.

body:
Thanks very much for adding "run on folder open" to tasks. I wish to request a "run on folder close" to complement this to e.g. stop services that are started on folder open.

I describe my use case in this comment: #54775 (comment).

Another use case is process clean-up. For instance, when using Debug Start with nodemon-hosted Node JS processes, if you quit VSCode "node" processes are left orphaned (and consuming CPU) as shown in Activity Monitor. I would like to do process clean-up in a folder-close task rather than manually in Activity Monitor after quitting VS Code.

title: Root-level @at-root selector in SCSS partial causes false syntax errors

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
<!-- Also please test using the latest insiders build to make sure your issue has not already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->

When placing an `@at-root` directive at the root-level of a SCSS file, Visual Studio Code's tokenizer seems to break completely, highlighting the `@at-root` and most other SCSS features in the proceeding block as syntax errors. Normally the `@at-root` selector would be useless at the root-level, but in a partial file which is included inside a selector from another file, it makes sense and is valid SCSS.

<!-- Use Help > Report Issue to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.30.1
- OS Version: Windows 10 build 1803

Reproduction files:

test.scss
```scss
$a-variable: 4px;

#main {
    @import "testpartial";
}

#main2 {
    background-color: red;
}
```

_testpartial.scss
```scss
.some-class {
    color: red;
}

@at-root #main2 .some-class {
    color: blue;
    padding-left: calc( #{$a-variable} + 8px );
}
```

Resulting CSS from `node-sass test.scss` (correct output):

```css
#main .some-class {
  color: red; }

#main2 .some-class {
  color: blue;
  padding-left: calc( 4px + 8px); }

#main2 {
  background-color: red; }
```

Screenshot of the false errors in Code:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/816612/50647099-62694a80-0f3d-11e9-90a4-77e5635801a2.png)


<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes

title: Debug Panels Location Options

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
The Debug Panel location is bound to the side bar, and thus, only can be positioned right or left.
![imagen](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1981463/50644757-82eed000-0f50-11e9-8979-07666244c993.png)

I presume web development has less issues with this, but working with C#, we use the debugger a lot. This puts in high evidence how unconfortable the debug panels location results (there are reasons that Visual Studio IDE has by default the debug panels at the bottom), forcing continually to resize the panels width in order to read the content in either of the panels (watchs, callstack, etc). 

So can we have an option to display the debug panels in the section where the consoles currently are, at the bottom?

title: preLaunchTask is awkward

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
I want to understand how to best use VS Code in this case.

Config in question: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/extensions/css-language-features/.vscode/launch.json

Problem:

- When I develop on css-language-features, I always run `yarn watch` in a terminal
- When I press F5, VS Code still runs the `preLaunchTask`, which can take quite a while
- Currently I comment out `preLaunchTask`, but I had to be careful not committing that to git
- I don't want to use task, since the task compiles but without watching, so each time I make a change, I need to wait fo a full recompile
- I can't just remove the `preLaunchTask`, since Martin uses it
- If I start using tasks by converting the current `compile` task to use `watch`, this will work fine if I "make change, then reload ExtHost window", but this won't work when I stop debugging session, since the next time I debug I need to run the task again

In my own extension, I've completely removed tasks for exactly this reason: https://github.com/vuejs/vetur/commit/502017a7f9925cdb68c961d4b4d88478563b5a41#diff-7fde71560fa9376d2d93a25b42d719f5

My current experience:

- When I open the project, I run `yarn watch` in terminal
- F5 brings up ExtHost instantly
- Recompile is fast

Is it possible to make `preLaunchTask` offer a similar experience?

title: Invert Regex Selection
body: I would like to see a flag in the Find / Replace modal that inverts the selection. In other words, everything starts out as selected / highlighted, then anything that matches the regular becomes un-selected / un-highlighted.

title: Behaviour of Page Up and Page Down keys is inconsistent with native Windows programs
body: If I open a file that is more than one screen long in Visual Studio Code (1.30.1), place the cursor at the top of the screen and press Page Down, the cursor moves to the bottom of the screen without moving the view. This behaviour is inconsistent with native Windows applications like Notepad or Visual Studio 2017. The expected behaviour is that the view should move one screen down, and the cursor should be on the line that is now on the top of the screen. The same goes for moving in the other direction with Page Up. The bug was reported earlier in #17686, but it was closed without a fix and is now locked.

title: Hotkey to get type information for the selected expression
Overriding the default 'type' command and then calling the default 'type' command results in significantly slower execution time
body:
- VSCode Version: 1.27.1
- OS Version: Windows 10 1809
- Machine processor: AMD A8-4555M APU Quad core clocked at 1.6GHz
- Graphics card: AMD Radeon HD 7600G

Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes (Aside from VSCodeVim - where the potential problem in the extensions API has been detected)

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Override the 'type' command with `vscode.commands.registerCommand`
2. Call the default 'type' command instead of the custom command
3. Note the difference in execution time in calling `vscode.commands.executeCommand('type', ...) ` when no custom type command has been registered, vs. calling `vscode.commands.executeCommand('default: type', ...)` (when a custom command has been registered/is overriding the default 'type' command). On my machine, the difference in execution time is consistently an order of magnitude (roughly 20ms vs 200ms) larger every time the executeCommand('default: type', ...) is called after overriding.

I have included some of my machine details here just-in-case - although I do doubt that they play any part in the issue here.

One of VSCode's most popular plugins, VSCodeVim/Vim, has an issue experienced by a fair share of the VSCodeVim community, as can be seen in an issue raised over a year ago in their repo -  VSCodeVim/Vim#2021. Typing in an editor window whilst this plugin is enabled results in an unbearably slow character render time, for a range of slower (and perhaps sometimes slighty-faster-than-slow) machines. During a screen-share a little while ago with @shawnaxsom, a contributor to the VSCodeVim community, we boiled the problem down to the 'type' command being overridden, and then having the default type command executed afterwards. For example, from my understanding of the VSCodeVim extension, the 'type' command is overridden like so:

`vscode.commands.registerCommand('type', async ...`

The default 'type' command is then called when needed, with code like this:

`await vscode.commands.executeCommand('default:type', { text });`

We measured the time taken for an ordinary (non-overridden) execution of the type command (which was roughly 20ms on my machine), vs. then calling 'default: type' command, which was always roughly 10x slower. Even though I am not familiar with the extensions API, this is puzzling, since these two calls should be doing exactly the same thing, yet calling `executeCommand('default: type', ...)` results in a much slower execution time of the default type command. I guess it has been an assumption that the source code in the VSCodeVim extension has been responsible for the severe typing slowness (or, it has only been occurring on slow machines, since it does not occur for everyone using the extension), but our screenshare led us to the conclusion that it appears to be this part of the extensions API which seems to be responsible. I imagine, also, that the much-slower execution time also occurs on faster machines, but it is simply not noticeable due to the fact that the faster processing/graphical power prevents the comparably slower call to the 'type' command being made visible rendering-wise. Even though it shouldn't matter, It is perhaps worth mentioning too, that even if the overridden (type) command is doing minimal work, as far as I know (I think we also tested this), the significant execution time difference still occurs.

title: Line-up, line-down seems to be broken when multiple lines are selected
body:
When using selecting multiple lines and moving them up/down with the Alt-Uparrow/Alt-Downarrow, the text gets malformed and messes up the buffer.

When doing this with a single line selected, it seems to work fine.

Note that this is not 100% of the time. But, if you select two lines and start moving them up, you will within a few moves see the corruption.

I see the same behavior on Windows, Linux, and Mac.

title: Multiple cursors + Word wrap + Selection
body:
- VSCode Version: 1.30.0
- OS Version: Windows 8.1 x86_64

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Copy the following text to a new file

Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetuer adipiscing elit. Aenean commodo ligula eget dolor. Aenean massa. Cum sociis natoque penatibus et magnis dis parturient montes, nascetur ridiculus mus. Donec quam felis, ultricies nec, pellentesque eu, pretium quis, sem. Nulla consequat massa quis enim.

Nulla consequat massa quis enim. Donec quam felis, ultricies nec, pellentesque eu, pretium quis, sem.

2. Enable "Word Wrap" and adjust the width of the editor to get a "word wrap" between "Donec quam" on the first line.

3. Select "Donec quam" and all occurrences Ctrl+Shift+L.
4. Press Left Arrow to deselect and move to beginning of selections.

Result: The cursors are now out of sync. If there is a word wrap inside the selection the cursor is 1 place more to the left than the selection start.

It also happens if there is a single cursor with selection but not that annoying to locate instead of when there are dozens of cursors.

Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes

title: Support the macOS system shortcuts for adding the next or previous line to the selection
body:
First, I want to thank the VS Code team for such a great product. I'm switching to VS Code from Sublime Text 3 (for the superior Unity and TypeScript support), and the vscode-sublime-keybindings extension has made the transition very smooth. However, there is a macOS keyboard shortcut I frequently use that doesn't appear to be supported in VS Code yet. The shortcut is referred to as "Shift-Option-Up Arrow" and "Shift-Option-Down Arrow" in [this Apple community thread](https://discussions.apple.com/thread/4738826):

| Key combination | What it does |
|----------------- |--------------|
| Shift-Option-Up Arrow | Extend text selection to the beginning of the current paragraph, then to the beginning of the following paragraph if pressed again|
| Shift-Option-Down Arrow | Extend text selection to the end of the current paragraph, then to the end of the following paragraph if pressed again|

I primarily use this shortcut in Sublime Text 3, but it also works in other native macOS apps, like TextEdit:

![desired-shortcut](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4952192/50533602-da2d1480-0afa-11e9-8033-f7966f40a737.gif)

VS Code does support the similar "Shift-Up Arrow" and "Shift-Down Arrow" shortcuts, however the functionality isn't identical. Rather than moving the cursor to the beginning or end of the line, the cursor stays at the same column. Again, here's a demo of that shortcut in TextEdit for comparison:

![existing-shortcut](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4952192/50533616-3001bc80-0afb-11e9-81c9-38019fa84942.gif)

While searching for a way to enable the desired shortcut in VS Code, I discovered that [there are shortcuts for enabling this functionality in the VS Code terminal](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/46761):
- `workbench.action.terminal.selectToPreviousLine`
- `workbench.action.terminal.selectToNextLine`

I looked at the [PR for those terminal shortcuts](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/pull/47991/files) with the hope that I could take a similar approach to add support for them in the editor, but I see that the PR deals with terminal-specific code.

I would love to see the "select to next/previous line" functionality available in the VS Code editor. If you know of a way of enabling that functionality, please let me know. In the meantime, I will switch to using a combination of "Shift-Up Arrow" and "Cmd+Shift+Left Arrow" to get the same behavior.

title: Panes splitting, auto closing
body:
I'm usually setting up 2 equal width,,horizontally splited panes and 1 full width under them( for things like extension's readme-s),
currently i found no way to create editor-width pane at bottom if you have at least 2 column ones (like was possible in VS), add to this a fact of that the full width line auto closes with it's last tab, and it becomes an issue (so if the last tab at bottom are accidently closed, its needed to close 1 of the upper panes, split to bottom and then split to side again),
this may look minor, but the splitting functionality just basically not complete, and ability to control tabs auto-closing behaviour are missed.

title: Duplicate / missing font declarations
body:
I noticed that we seem to either declare some fonts redundantly or are missing font declarations for CYK languages.

**Redundant Declarations**
* [x] [`.monaco-workbench .terminal-message-widget`](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/f886dd4fb84bb82478bfab4a68cd3f31b32f5eb5/src/vs/workbench/parts/terminal/electron-browser/media/widgets.css#L14) @Tyriar this came in via https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/commit/7bcdf81179a6575082c9536b9c1abb32a4ef6a6f and its not clear to me why the rule in `shell.css` is not good enough
* [ ] [`SuggestEnabledInput`](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/f886dd4fb84bb82478bfab4a68cd3f31b32f5eb5/src/vs/workbench/parts/codeEditor/electron-browser/suggestEnabledInput.ts#L284) @sandy081 @roblourens seems to be used in settings editor and extensions view, its not clear to me why the font has to be declared like that
* [x] [`.context-view.monaco-menu-container`](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/f886dd4fb84bb82478bfab4a68cd3f31b32f5eb5/src/vs/base/browser/ui/menu/menu.css#L119) and [`.menubar .menubar-menu-items-holder.monaco-menu-container`](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/f886dd4fb84bb82478bfab4a68cd3f31b32f5eb5/src/vs/base/browser/ui/menu/menu.css#L184) and [`.monaco-shell .monaco-menu-container .monaco-menu`](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/f886dd4fb84bb82478bfab4a68cd3f31b32f5eb5/src/vs/workbench/electron-browser/media/shell.css#L19) @sbatten maybe a leftover from when the context view was not rooted within the shell? I would think we can remove the 2 rules in the widget itself (provided you drop in a rule for the standalone editor) and then we can even remove the third rule in `shell.css` possibly?

**Missing Declarations**
* issue reporter
* process explorer

@RMacfarlane both seem to declare the font as in `shell.css` (which is right because these are in separate windows) but miss the language specific overrides it seems (e.g. `:lang(ja)`, `:lang(ko)`, `lang(zh-Hans)`. If we support localization in these 2 windows as well, we need to have the same font rules. I also noticed that some fonts seem to be declared redundantly (e.g. `html` and `textarea`)

//cc @jrieken

title: Add option to disable markdown highlighting in JSDoc comments
javascript: highlight matching parens and braces in regular expression literals

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
Regular expressions can become pretty complex. It takes a lot of time to visually parse what's going on and where a capture group starts or ends.
Consider the following regular expression I wrote 10 months ago:

```js
/\/[/*]\s*wotan-(enable|disable)((?:-next)?-line)?(\s+(?:(?:[\w-]+\/)*[\w-]+\s*,\s*)*(?:[\w-]+\/)*[\w-]+)?\s*?(?:$|\*\/)/mg
```

I'm having a really hard time to edit this thing. It would help a lot if matching parens and/or brackets were highlighted similar to the highlighting in regular Javascript code.

Online regex builders (like regex101.com) and probably other IDEs support such a feature.

body: Issue Type: Feature Request Enabling font ligatures is currently only possible for text in the main text editor. It would be great if there are additional settings for enabling this feature for hints/tooltips, terminal, debug console, output and problems panels. `=>` with font ligatures enabled (editor): ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/36337818/50427086-b8cfec80-089e-11e9-9f23-05f872f2a557.png) Font ligatures missing: ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/36337818/50427096-efa60280-089e-11e9-8c2c-cc0fda6a042a.png) VS Code version: Code - Insiders 1.31.0-insider (e02e44464c02d617b98d0a3265bf5efef7794436, 2018-12-21T06:20:35.852Z) OS version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.17134
